p: In the Finish DIPP cohort study, the appearance of autoantibodies showed a seasonal pattern with a significantly higher proportion in the fall and winter [ 24]. Thus, autoimmunity follows the same pattern as viral infection and may not just be directly caused by virus infection, but rather by a combination of unfavorable events at the same time, i.e., higher inflammation in the winter, when diet often changes to sweeter and fattier food with less exercise outside and low vitamin D levels because of limited sunlight exposure, which are all factors that have been independently shown to be associated with T1D [ 19] ( Figure 1). Furthermore, there is the increased risk for another auto-immune disease [ 25].
